content: I have shared my observations with the LlamaIndex team as well.

Hi @kacperlukawski I investigated this issue a bit more and found something interesting, so wanted to let you know:

In `llama_index/vector_stores/qdrant/base.py`,

both `def _create_collection()` and `async def _acreate_collection()` have this exception handler (you pointed this out earlier)

```except (ValueError, UnexpectedResponse) as exc:
            if "already exists" not in str(exc):
                raise exc  # noqa: TRY201
            logger.warning(
                "Collection %s already exists, skipping collection creation.",
                collection_name,
            )```

The problem is, this exception handler (`except (ValueError, UnexpectedResponse) as exc`) does not get triggered for Qdrant gRPC clients. For HTTP clients it works fine. For gRPC, I just used a generic exception handler `except Exception  as exc` instead of the above, and that able to handle the exception. Since I'm using gRPC, the application was crashing due to an unhandled exception.

We construct the actix HTTP server here: https://github.com/qdrant/qdrant/blob/d0baa5ef4a4bc2c597b28d0e1f1011262be8ed4d/src/actix/mod.rs#L55-L191
We do not specify any custom keep-alive value.

According to the documentation, the default keep alive is 5 seconds: https://docs.rs/actix-web/latest/actix_web/struct.HttpServer.html#method.keep_alive

- each node will get 4 'replicated shards'

```
client = qdrant_client.QdrantClient(host=QDRANT_HOST,
                                    grpc_port=QDRANT_GRPC_PORT,
                                    prefer_grpc=True,
                                    api_key=QDRANT_API_KEY)
vector_store = QdrantVectorStore(client=client,
                                  collection_name=collection_name,
                                  batch_size=20)
index = VectorStoreIndex.from_vector_store(vector_store=vector_store,
                                           service_context=service_context)
for document in documents:
    try:
        log.info(f"SETUP: Source {source_id} Updating document")
        index.update_ref_doc(
            document,
            update_kwargs={
                "delete_kwargs": {
                    "delete_from_docstore": True
                }
            },
        )
    except Exception as err:
        log.info(f"SETUP: Source {source_id} Error: {err}")
        log.info(f"SETUP: Source {source_id} Update failed, trying insert")
        index.insert(document)
```

This code performs well when processing documents one at a time. However, it encounters issues under multiple concurrent requests. Some requests fail with the error: `Wrong input: Collection <collection name> already exists!`. Also keep in mind 

```
Restoration of snapshots is limited to Qdrant clusters sharing the same minor version. For instance, a snapshot captured in v1.4.1 is exclusive to restoration in clusters of version v1.4.x, where x is equal to or greater than 1.
```

So you only have one node. 

You can use this to create snapshot by collection: https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/snapshots/#create-snapshot

Hey, I was wrong. I am looking at the API spec and realized that actually you can specify how many shards and the replication factor for each shard key.
See this https://qdrant.github.io/qdrant/redoc/index.html#tag/collections/operation/create_shard_key

> But would each shard be subdivided into segments according to size?
Yes, shards are made up of segments, and these segments have a fixed size (in kB) called `optimizers: { max_segment_size }` in the collection config. The default value is 20000 * number_of_cpus

Hi @david.wilmot. When using custom sharding, the other shard parameters (number of shards and replication) apply to all shard keys, but there is no granular way of specifying number of shards for a specific shard key.

> For example, if you have 10 shard keys and a collection config with these settings:
> 
> {
>     "shard_number": 1,
>     "sharding_method": "custom",
>     "replication_factor": 2
> }
> 
> Then you will have 1 * 10 * 2 = 20 total physical shards in the collection.

https://qdrant.tech/documentation/guides/distributed_deployment/#user-defined-sharding

Unfortunately, Fully scaling down a cluster is not supported, as block storage can only be scaled up.

The other option would be that you pick another package, and we manually scale down the cluster‚Äôs RAM and CPU for you.

Here's a little longer explanation, in case someone else is confused by the error message:

In Qdrant you can have named vectors, which allows to use multiple different vectors for each point, for example: a text embedding, and an image embedding. 
When you create a collection, you can set the configuration for these named vectors, and when you do your searches, you need to specify which of the named vectors you want to search through. However, when a vector is configured without a name (known as the default vector for the collection), the designated name is actually an empty string (`""`).
The error here is saying that you did not set up any default vector, hence the double space in `params for  are not`.

TLDR; (and solution): you should **check your collection info** to see what is the correct vector name you should specify for your searches.

You can set `QDRANT__SERVICE__HOST=::0` environment variable (or as part of the config file)
